Column: social media polices plagiarism

  • By Noel Cody
  • reesenews director of audience engagement
Nov. 05 7:49 am
  • 40754 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F2010%2F11%2F05%2Fcooksource%2F4075%2FColumn%3A+social+media+polices+plagiarism2010-11-05+11%3A49%3A05Noel+Codyhttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F%3Fp%3D4075
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

Social media was in an uproar today over a blogger, a cooking magazine and an allegedly stolen apple tart recipe.

In 2005, U.S. student blogger Monica Gaudio wrote an article called “The Tale of Two Tarts” on her Gode Cookery website. Last week, Gaudio learned from a friend that a recipe from her article had been reprinted with her byline and without her permission in this October’s issue of Cooks Source Magazine.

This is a clear-cut case of copyright infringement, and in a non-Internet world it would have likely taken Gaudio months to litigate a claim against the magazine. But when the information got out last night, social media allowed it to spread quickly into a form of digital mob justice, initiating a backlash against the magazine.

The incident began when Gaudio wrote a complaint letter to Judith Griggs, editor of Cooks Source, asking what had happened and how they had obtained the article.

According to Gaudio’s blog, it was only after several e-mails that Griggs asked Gaudio what she wanted. Gaudio responded that she wanted apologies both on Facebook and in the magazine, as well as a $130 donation to the Columbia School of Journalism.

Griggs responded with a message that sparked today’s social media backlash:

“Yes Monica, I have been doing this for 3 decades, having been an editor at The Voice, Housitonic Home and Connecticut Woman Magazine. I do know about copyright laws. It was ‘my bad’ indeed, and, as the magazine is put together in long sessions, tired eyes and minds somethings forget to do these things.
But honestly Monica, the web is considered ‘public domain’ and you should be happy we just didn’t ‘lift’ your whole article and put someone else’s name on it!”

She went on to say that Gaudio should compensate her personally for editing and republishing her work.

Social media allows any person to publish a message to a potentially large audience: Gaudio published her post about the whole debacle late last night, and her audience has grown quickly.

Four-hundred and thirty comments have been left on the original post, the Cooks Source Facebook page has been filled with comments reprimanding and ridiculing the magazine, Twitter is abuzz about the topic and a fake Cooks Source Twitter account has been created (@cookssource), as well as a conversation using the #crooksource hash tag.

The controversy has even received media attention from the Guardian, BoingBoing and others. Protesters have taken over the “discussions” section of the Cooks Source Facebook page, filling it with discussions of copyright laws, an open letter to the magazine, and a variety of spam messages.

But that’s not all. People have been digging up the dirt on how Cooks Source plagiarized not only from Gaudio, but from Food Network, Martha Stewart, Paula Deen and NPR, among others.

Now that Gaudio has incited a crowd of enthusiastic protesters to seek out infringements, they’re being discovered in a variety of places — and quickly. A thread on that same Cooks Source Facebook discussion board has been tracking a growing list of plagiarized articles — the thread has received 82 posts in its first three hours, between 2:30 and 5:30 p.m. on Thursday.

Today, information can spread quickly, large-scale collaboration and action can happen spontaneously, and a few unjust actions and ignorant comments in an email can easily spark a public uproar. Cooks Source now has a public relations disaster and several potential copyright infringement lawsuits on their hands.

It’s surprising that, in our connected world, Griggs believed she could act the way she did and get away with it.

Noel Cody, a senior from St. Louis, is director of audience engagement for the Reese Felts Digital News Project.

  1. There are actually several really great Cook's Source fake twitters. They're mostly funny because of Griggs' angry cease and desist requests. What a clown. (Perhaps she is a fake herself?)

    Comment by Jon on November 4, 2010 at 7:02 pm

  2. "It's surprising that, in our connected world, Griggs believed she could act the way she did and get away with it."

    I think she never expected this to happen because, let's face it, this was a matter of luck. Not every incident will go viral; one of the core events here was Gaudio's friendship with Nick Mamatas on LiveJournal and Mamatas' posting about what had happened. John Scalzi read Mamatas' post and blogged about the incident. He also tweeted Gaudio's post and that tweet was picked up and retweeted by Neil Gaiman. Gaiman has 1,500,998 followers on Twitter, so his tweet was probably highly influential in setting off this storm.

    In addition, I would say that most of those who follow Mamatas, Scalzi and Gaiman are either fellow writers or avid readers, so they were more likely to have a strong feeling about what Griggs had done — as well as her seemingly flippant attitude towards it. Anyone who is involved with the written word knows what a sacrilege it is to have one's work treated without respect.

    A lot of things happen to a lot of people, and are blogged and/or tweeted, but never become public knowledge this way. It's not always easy to predict when something will go viral and become a firestorm over social media and the Internet. True, there is always the possibility of it happening — but when it comes to possibilities, many people tend to think, "It'll never happen to me." I also speculate that Griggs felt "safer" because hers was a small publication intended only for local distribution, and furthermore, distributed for free. She didn't think anyone would bother to check, and she probably thought that even if they did find out, they wouldn't make a big deal out of it, since it was, in a way, "small potatoes" compared to other nationally-distributed magazines.

    Comment by @wilfulsunflower on November 5, 2010 at 1:59 pm

  3. Well, it was posted to "reddit" first. Front page of "reddit" is basically viral by definition.

    Comment by Jon on November 5, 2010 at 7:01 pm

  4. Very interesting. Using this article for my social media class Discussion Board Assignment

    Comment by @ehornsbycomm on February 15, 2011 at 1:35 am
